questions.text: Which of the following pathways are responsible for the pathogenesis of ALS?
questions.correct_answer: B. Ubiquitin-proteasome pathway

questions.text: Which of the following case scenarios is not indicative of metastatic calcification?

options.label: A
options.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of chronic renal failure presented with shortness of breath and bilateral lung opacities on chest X-ray.

options.label: B
options.text: A 45-year-old female with spinal tuberculosis complained of back pain.

options.label: C
options.text: A 30-year-old male with a long-standing history of heavy milk and calcium carbonate intake now experiencing recurrent kidney stones.

options.label: D
options.text: A 55-year-old female with sarcoidosis demonstrated elevated levels of serum vitamin D and calcium.

questions.correct_answer: B. A 45-year-old female with spinal tuberculosis complained of back pain.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about dystrophic calcification?

options.label: A
options.text: It occurs in damaged or necrotic tissues.

options.label: B
options.text: It is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in normal tissues.

options.label: C
options.text: It is often seen in areas of chronic inflammation.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in normal tissues.
questions.explanation:
Dystrophic Calcification

Metastatic Calcification
  • Dead or degenerating tissues are seen.
  • There will be a normal blood calcium count.

Some examples:

  • Dead Parasite
  • TB
  • Atheroma
  • Monckeberg Sclerosis
 

It is also called calcific medial degeneration.

  • It happens in the tunica media.
  • Calcium occurs blue in color
  • It occurs only as an old age phenomenon without any clinical significance.

Psammoma Bodies:

  • It is present as a concentric lamellation.
  • It shows an onion-peel appearance
  • Seen in:
  • Papillary carcinoma of thyroid.
  • Papillary renal cell cancer.
  • meningioma.
  • Prolactinoma
  • Serous Cystadenocarcinoma of ovary.
  • Normal tissues are seen.
  • The blood calcium level is elevated
  • The most common organ affected due to
  • Metastatic calcification - The Lungs

Some Examples:

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Cancer:
  • RCC and Breast cancer show an

increase of calcium.

  • Vitamin D intoxication
  • Milk alkali syndrome
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Sarcoidosis

questions.text: Which of the following stains is not typically employed for the detection of lipid accumulation in histological samples?
questions.correct_answer: D. Toluidine blue

Stain

questions.text: Which of the following pathological conditions is associated with the 'Tabby cat' effect?
questions.correct_answer: A. Diphtheria myocarditis

questions.text: Which of the following pathological conditions involves the accumulation of pigments through exogenous sources?
questions.correct_answer: D. Coal worker’s pneumoconiosis
questions.explanation:
Exogenous pigments

Endogenous pigments

They originate from external sources and are introduced into the body through environmental exposure or ingestion.

They are naturally produced within the body as a result of metabolic processes.

E.g.

  • Carbon pigment (exogenous carbon or coal dust)
  • Tattoo ink (skin tattooing)

E.g.

  • Melanin
  • Hemosiderin
  • Bilirubin
  • Lipofuscin
  • Porphyrins
  • Homogentisic acid (darkens on exposure to air)

questions.text: Which type of cell death prevents metastasis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Anoikis

questions.text: Which of the following is true about programmed necrosis?

options.label: D
options.text: It helps kill the Herpes simplex virus.

questions.correct_answer: A. Caspase-independent programmed cell death.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is not a component of ‘eat-me signals’ of efferocytosis?
questions.correct_answer: D. Fas Ligand

questions.text: Match the following apoptotic genes with their functions: 1. BCL2 , MCL1 a. Allows cytochrome c leakage 2. BAX, BAK b. Initiates apoptosis when upregulated 3. BAD, BID, NOXA c. Prevents leakage of cytochrome C from the cytosol
Which of the following statements about apoptosis is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Characterized by the activation of caspases leading to DNA fragmentation.

options.label: B
options.text: Inflammatory response and release of damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs).

options.label: C
options.text: Chromatin condensation and formation of cytoplasmic blebs.

options.label: D
options.text: Eliminates cells that are injured beyond repair without eliciting a host reaction.

questions.correct_answer: B. Inflammatory response and release of damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs).

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair among the following
questions.correct_answer: C. Fat necrosis- Pancreatic lipase- Omentum
questions.explanation:
Type of necrosis

Pathology

Conditions

Coagulative 

Lysosomal enzymes derived from

infiltrating leukocytes

Ischemia in all organs except the brain

Liquefactive

Microbes stimulating leukocyte enzymes

Bacterial and fungal infections

Ischemia in brain

Caseous

Formation of granuloma by lymphocytes and activated macrophages (giant cells, epithelioid cells).

Tuberculosis,Fungal infections( Histoplasmosis, Coccidioidomycosis) ,Syphilis

Gangrenous

Ischemia and necrosis 

Lower and upper limb

Fat necrosis

Pancreatic enzymes leak out of

damaged acinar cells

Pancreatitis, traumatic fat necrosis of the breast. 

Fibrinoid 

Immune reactions involving blood vessels

Polyarteritis nodosa, SLE, Arthus reaction, rheumatic heart disease, malignant hypertension, etc.

questions.text: Based on the provided image, which features are indicative of the type of gangrene depicted?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of gas bubbles in the affected tissue

options.label: B
options.text: Formation of bullae filled with fluid

options.label: C
options.text: Dry, shrunken, and mummified appearance with a clear demarcation

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of foul-smelling discharge and crepitus on palpation

questions.correct_answer: C. Dry, shrunken, and mummified appearance with a clear demarcation
questions.explanation:
Dry gangrene

Wet gangrene

Site 

Commonly limbs 

More common in the bowel

Mechanism

Arterial occlusion

More commonly, venous obstruction

Pathology

Coagulative necrosis

Liquefactive necrosis

Macroscopy

Organ dry, shrunken, and black

Part is moist, soft, swollen, rotten, and dark

Line of demarcation

Present - at the junction between healthy and gangrenous part

No clear-cut line of demarcation

Infection 

No infection 

Infection present, with pus formation.

Prognosis

Generally better due to little septicemia.

Generally poor due to profound toxaemia.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not involve fibrinoid necrosis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Atherosclerosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the role of telomerase in cellular ageing?

options.label: A
options.text: Telomerase accelerates ageing by reducing the length of telomeres with each cell division

options.label: B
options.text: Telomerase maintains the constant telomere length in somatic cells throughout their lifespan.

options.label: C
options.text: Telomerase prevents the shortening of telomeres by adding DNA sequences to the ends of chromosomes, thus potentially extending cell's lifespan.

options.label: D
options.text: Telomerase is a Ribozyme delaying cell aging.

questions.correct_answer: C. Telomerase prevents the shortening of telomeres by adding DNA sequences to the ends of chromosomes, thus potentially extending cell's lifespan.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary function of chaperones within the cellular environment?

options.label: A
options.text: Facilitating the degradation of misfolded proteins

options.label: B
options.text: Promoting protein folding and preventing misfolding

options.label: C
options.text: Catalyzing enzymatic reactions by providing a scaffold

questions.correct_answer: B. Promoting protein folding and preventing misfolding
questions.explanation:
Disease

Misfolded protein

Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease

Prions

Cystic fibrosis

Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR)

questions.text: What is the primary function of superoxide dismutase (SOD) in cells?

options.label: C
options.text: Neutralization of superoxide anion radicals (O2•-) into hydrogen peroxide (H2O2)

questions.correct_answer: C. Neutralization of superoxide anion radicals (O2•-) into hydrogen peroxide (H2O2)
questions.explanation:
Non-Enzymatic

Enzymatic
  • Vitamin E, A, and C.

(Vitamin A is not an antioxidant in the aqueous humor of eye.

  • Se, Mn, Zn.
  • Superoxide dismutase.
  • Catalase.
  • Glutathione peroxidase.

questions.text: Which of the following is a telltale sign of free radical injury in cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased antioxidant levels in the cell

options.label: C
options.text: Generation of Lipofuscin and stress markers such as malondialdehyde (MDA)

questions.correct_answer: C. Generation of Lipofuscin and stress markers such as malondialdehyde (MDA)

questions.text: Match the following descriptions of the nuclear changes in irreversible cell injury. I. Pyknosis a. Nuclear fragmentation II. Karyorrhexis b. Dissolution of nucleus III. Karyolysis c. Shrinking of the nucleus and clumping of nuclear chromatin
questions.correct_answer: C. I-c, II-a, III-b
questions.explanation:
Pyknosis

Shrinking of the nucleus and clumping of nuclear chromatin

Karyorrhexis

Nuclear fragmentation

Karyolysis

Dissolution of nucleus

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of reversible cell injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Large amorphous densities in the mitochondria

options.label: D
options.text: Detachment of ribosomes from granular ER

questions.correct_answer: A. Large amorphous densities in the mitochondria

questions.text: Identify the correct combination of most and least sensitive cells to hypoxia.

options.label: A
options.text: Most sensitive - hepatocytes and least sensitive - Lymphocytes

options.label: B
options.text: Most sensitive - bone marrow cells and least sensitive - nerve cells

options.label: C
options.text: Most sensitive - retina and least sensitive - adipose tissue

options.label: D
options.text: Most sensitive - neurons and least sensitive - fibroblasts

questions.correct_answer: D. Most sensitive - neurons and least sensitive - fibroblasts

questions.text: What is the most common cause of cell injury?
questions.correct_answer: A. Hypoxia

questions.text: Which type of atrophy is observed in a patient with smaller and weaker muscles who is bedridden for several weeks?
questions.correct_answer: A. Disuse atrophy

questions.text: Which of the following biomarkers is associated with autophagy?
questions.correct_answer: D. LC3

questions.text: What is the mechanism by which chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA) targets misfolded proteins for degradation?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct uptake by lysosomes via endocytosis

options.label: B
options.text: Activation of mTOR leading to inhibition of ULK1 complex

options.label: C
options.text: Selective degradation of damaged or dysfunctional mitochondria

options.label: D
options.text: Binding of chaperones to misfolded proteins, followed by lysosomal entry via LAMP2A for autophagy

questions.correct_answer: D. Binding of chaperones to misfolded proteins, followed by lysosomal entry via LAMP2A for autophagy

questions.text: Which cellular process is primarily responsible for the degradation and recycling of unnecessary or dysfunctional cellular components?
questions.correct_answer: A. Autophagy

questions.text: How do “Sirtuins” contribute to cellular ageing?

options.label: B
options.text: By enhancing cell repair mechanisms and exerting anti-ageing effects.

options.label: C
options.text: By functioning as histone acetyltransferases, promoting chromatin condensation.

questions.correct_answer: B. By enhancing cell repair mechanisms and exerting anti-ageing effects.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the concept of the Hayflick Limit?

options.label: A
options.text: The ageing of cells is not determined by telomere length.

options.label: B
options.text: It refers to the age at which cells cease all metabolic activities and undergo apoptosis.

options.label: C
options.text: A cell typically undergoes 20-40 cell divisions before reaching senescence.

options.label: D
options.text: It represents the average number of times a cell can divide before experiencing replicative senescence.

questions.correct_answer: D. It represents the average number of times a cell can divide before experiencing replicative senescence.
